content:
Our automated analysis identified 940 high-confidence duplicate payment groups totalling £3.4 million in Hyndburn Borough Council's published spending data. These are cases where the same supplier received the same amount on the same date with the same reference number — either genuine overpayments or errors in the council's transparency data.

What Makes These "High-Confidence" Duplicates?

We applied strict matching criteria to minimise false positives. Every flagged duplicate matches on all four fields:

  1. Supplier name — identical after normalisation
  2. Payment amount — exact match to the penny
  3. Payment date — same day
  4. Reference number — identical transaction reference

When all four fields match, there is either a legitimate explanation (such as genuinely identical services on the same day) or something has gone wrong.

Scale of the Problem

Metric Hyndburn Burnley Pendle
Duplicate groups9405031,311
Total duplicate value£3,400,000£2,478,616£2,700,000
As % of total spend1.6%1.1%2.1%

Hyndburn has the highest value of duplicates at £3.4 million — nearly £1 million more than Burnley despite a comparable total spend.

The HM Land Registry Pattern

One supplier stands out for sheer volume: HM Land Registry appears with 2,422 tiny transactions averaging just £5 each. While land registry fees are legitimate, the volume of micro-transactions is unusual and worth investigating. Why is the council processing thousands of individual small payments rather than consolidating them?

Two Possible Explanations

As with all councils we've analysed, there are two possibilities:

  1. Data publishing errors: The council's transparency reporting system is creating duplicate records in the CSV files — meaning taxpayers cannot trust the published data
  2. Actual duplicate payments: The council is genuinely paying suppliers twice for the same work — meaning £3.4 million of public money may have been wasted

Either explanation represents a failure. The council should conduct an internal audit to determine which payments are genuine duplicates and which are data errors — and publish the results.

All figures derived from publicly available Hyndburn Borough Council spending data published under the Local Government Transparency Code. Duplicate detection methodology consistent across all three council analyses.
